Subject: Re: [junit] Time values as reported by JUnit 3.6

Hi Dennis,

On 7/10/07, Dennis <dennisk@...> wrote:
>  We  are trying to use the times reported by JUnit as a benchmark value.
>  Is that reasonable?

I guess that depends on what you mean by "use as a benchmark value"?


On 7/10/07, Dennis <dennisk@...> wrote:
>  We understand that the setUp() Time is included and have taken
>  some measures to eliminate that time element but we do not know if
>  the tearDown() time is also included in the reported time.

If setUp() is included then I'd say it's almost certain that
tearDown() is included, too. After all, those method calls are made
from the same level of the call stack. This should be easy to verify
by adding a "Thread.sleep(5000)" to a tearDown() method and seeing
whether it affects the reported execution time. Or then you  could
just read the source, of course.


On 7/10/07, Dennis <dennisk@...> wrote:
>  If the tearDown time cannot be eliminated or if our use of the Time
>  values is completely off-base, then I would ask if going to JUnit4
>  would be better insofar as we could make use of the
>  @Before/@BeforeClass/@After/AfterClass constructs, hoping that they
>  would eliminate the set up and tear down times?

No, @Before and @After won't eliminate the setup and teardown
times--they're just a new syntax for achieving the same behavior as
JUnit 3.x achieved with setUp() and tearDown().


Lasse

-- 
Lasse Koskela
